text: this makes me think that also the oppositional drive in solar punk is not destructive but creative. Maybe there's some true lack of opposition? It is as if, even the oppositional part presents istself as an alternative to the status quo, without truly challengin the status quo's infrastructures... a bit like "come to our side, live with us in our alternative organization" while the rest of the world is not truly challenged and keeps scaling its weapons of destruction. It would be nice to hather some sources that focus more on solare punk also as a material attack on mainstream infrastructures, I am sure these stories are also out there

title: Planetary Infrastructure as Resistance: Solarpunk and Web3 – ZORA ZINE
Planetary Infrastructure as Resistance: Solarpunk and Web3 – ZORA ZINE
text:
found really thought provoking what Phoebe Tickell says in the Green pill poadcast about decentralization. Something along the lines of the fact that a decentralized structure is not necessarily a fair and just structure, as well as organization and coordination would not necessarily lead to harmony. She identifys the problem not in decision making structures but in imagination, which shapes levels of human development, capacity for ethics, values and a collective morality.
She reckons the issue is at the level of accountability and transparency, you can have really unhealthy decentralized systems where there's still power imbalance, decentralization can hid soft influence.

here's her references: https://medium.com/the-tuning-fork/hierarchy-is-not-the-problem-892610f5d9c0
and
https://www.jofreeman.com/joreen/tyranny.htm
exact: Decentralization, in the sense that authority is moved away from a central governing body to local or individual agents, is thus implicitly embedded in this description.
suffix: Solarpunk is often, also in the

selector.suffix: Solarpunk is often, also in the

text:
Are not all utopias others' dystopias? 


It seems to me that wether 'positive' or 'negative', a dream/nightmare of a u/dys-topia is by essence totalizing.


I feel that we should go beyond both dystopia and utopia, as a political goal at least - instead of pushing for a utopian totality, we could try to encourage some (unpredictable) diversity

title: Planetary Infrastructure as Resistance: Solarpunk and Web3 – ZORA ZINE
Planetary Infrastructure as Resistance: Solarpunk and Web3 – ZORA ZINE
text: How can we consider scalability in our 'solarpunk' solutions? Decentralisation and local organisation seems to be a core value of solarpunk ideas, but appears contradictory when we  try to scale on a global level.
prefix: by the tragedy of the commons.⁹
exact: “Regenerative economic tools” they argue “are solarpunk.” But to build these tools (and common goods) needed for social progress at the planetary scale, global coordination and large-scale implementation is needed, and the question is whether that is still solarpunk, too.

selector.exact: “Regenerative economic tools” they argue “are solarpunk.” But to build these tools (and common goods) needed for social progress at the planetary scale, global coordination and large-scale implementation is needed, and the question is whether that is still solarpunk, too.
selector.prefix: by the tragedy of the commons.⁹

title: Planetary Infrastructure as Resistance: Solarpunk and Web3 – ZORA ZINE
Planetary Infrastructure as Resistance: Solarpunk and Web3 – ZORA ZINE
text: Yes... perhaps we could think of tools with global standards, for better coordination, but with local applications and appropriations (kind of like a free software, which can have local adaptations but is addressed to a global community and as such, conforms to certain technological standards)

title: Planetary Infrastructure as Resistance: Solarpunk and Web3 – ZORA ZINE
Planetary Infrastructure as Resistance: Solarpunk and Web3 – ZORA ZINE
text: is the question of scalability a bit besides the point? i have to think about anna lowenhaupt-ting's text on non-scalability... the problem of scale.. or the problem of the promise of scalability is that it does not account for the non-scalable effects.. isnt it a fallacy to think you can scale a "solution" such as solar-energy up and down and not think about what does not scale or translate through these transitions. i find solarpunk limiting in that context...  it may be the sun that is a super abundant resource in some context and may fulfil its regenerational promise but in another context the sun may be perceived as causing a lot of harm and rather than sparking future imagination is a cause of distress. other forms of regenerative resources and practices may be fitting better in these contexts

title: Planetary Infrastructure as Resistance: Solarpunk and Web3 – ZORA ZINE
Planetary Infrastructure as Resistance: Solarpunk and Web3 – ZORA ZINE
text: I find myself in line with this. I find the pursuit of scalability as a matter surrounded by gloomy vibes. It's one thought that puts you immediately in the position of "thinking in the place of others". Inthis case, thinking that one technological solution will work for others too.. As one programmer would know well, there are endless ways to reach the same result. Makes me wonder if commoning knowledges  and practices with your neighbours (who are somebody else's neighbours) could be a better way to scale solutions... letting other learn and take what they need, rework on it etc (a bith on the line on mauss gifts thingy in anthropology)

title: Planetary Infrastructure as Resistance: Solarpunk and Web3 – ZORA ZINE
Planetary Infrastructure as Resistance: Solarpunk and Web3 – ZORA ZINE
text:
sounds really interesting as a thought-movement, actually: 
> "The new materialisms are a range of contemporary perspectives in the arts, humanities and social sciences that have in common a theoretical and practical ‘turn to matter’. Many new materialists treat their work as discontinuous with the historical materialism of Hegel and Marx, whereas others recognise a connection via the micropolitical working of power, politics and biopolitics.  The materiality addressed in these new materialisms is relational, plural, open, complex, uneven and contingent; cuts across dualistic boundaries between natural and social worlds; and for some new materialist scholars is invested with a vitality or liveliness"
[source](https://globalsocialtheory.org/topics/new-materialism/)
